(9) The Decline of the Kookas

No one can produce convincing evidence. Those who portray Kukke Baba Balak Singh or Baba Ram Singh on the basis of their personal qualities only as the manipulative leaders of the Namdhari sect would not be tempted to distort ancient Sikh history.

Based on the experience gained at the time of writing this book, I am compelled to say that in order to convey to our elders the best of our imaginations, writers who consider it a great service to blend fictional stories into their biographies do as much injustice as these writers do to the elderly as their bitter adversaries may not

. At some point in time, it becomes difficult to dissect reality and adulteration, as a result of which many skeptical, thoughtful readers reject even a single true fact with suspicion. Therefore, in history, the benefits of psychoanalytic adulterations are many times more than permanent, which can never be undone.

In the eyes of Die Sardhal devotees, prophecies and unforeseen miracles seem to have become an essential part of the biographies of great men, who are not even worth taking home from them, but they realize that they thus make any intimate, ghostly, unusual, even a historical fact suspicious to the prying eyes

. The same thing has happened and is happening to the lives of Bab Balak Singh and Baba Ram Singh, the leaders of the Kuka sect. So it is becoming difficult to say how much of their life has gone well, how much half and how much fourth-fifth.

Baba Balak Singh Chranki has been writing'Bhai'to himself till the end, so we have also used the same word for him in the script, no other word, which may be against his wishes, was considered fit to be used. Similarly, Baba Ram Singh also used to say'Bhai ', so we have written this in the beginning. Finally, keeping in mind his status and respect, we have written'Baba '.
